nodes.text: Boolean-network-based partial modelling can serve as an inductive discovery procedure to develop economic theory and produce predictive models of the economy
Partial models should be used as cognitive instruments in a regime of exploration rather than as final comprehensive theories
Boolean networks (BNs) have been applied in systems biology and are sometimes reported to yield high predictive power
In practice the term predict in systems biology often means reproducing known or unsurprising results or calibration, not blind-tested forecasting of novel events
The proposed BN integration strategy requires simplification such as excluding node values that produce multiple steady states and removing feedback loops to avoid oscillations
BNs can include qualitative components with minimal data and can be converted into continuous dynamical systems configured as ordinary differential equations (ODEs)
A sufficiently complicated model is flexible and can be made to match known data but may be poor at making non-trivial predictions
Models patched together by joining and pruning partial models do not necessarily produce better or more realistic models of complex systems
Example: a Boolean network model predicted fission yeast cell cycle sequence, illustrating reproduction of known biological sequences
Calibration or reproduction of existing results is much more common than blind-tested prediction in practice
Adding model detail increases the number of unknown parameters and structural uncertainty, producing sloppy parameters that cannot be determined from data
Hidden opposing feedback loops produce complex unstable behaviour and are hard to identify from data; removing them to stabilize models can make models less realistic

Empirical examples show structure matters more than size: stochastic effects in yeast were invisible to any ODE model, drug companies use combined ODE/agent-based models, and simple models sometimes outperform large parameterized models

Therefore the BN patching and pruning strategy is unlikely to resolve key problems in economic modelling because difficult features like feedbacks, human behaviour, and money have often been pruned and many parameters are indeterminate

Alternative proposal: use a dashboard approach that keeps a range of model types mostly separate so each model captures complementary aspects of reality without attempting to form a single comprehensive patched model
Investigate incentives and funding sources before combining models, because institutional incentives shape assumptions and the questions asked and can bias modelling outcomes
